title: Default MainActor isolation (evaluate + possible adoption)
description:
Context
- Strict concurrency checking is now enabled repo-wide via SwiftPM swiftSettings (-strict-concurrency=complete + -warn-concurrency).
- We deferred Swift 6's default actor isolation decision. This bead evaluates making UI code main-thread-safe by default.

Goal
- Evaluate enabling default actor isolation to MainActor for the UI/executable targets (FolderBarApp + FolderBar) to make UI-thread correctness the default.

Non-goals
- Do not change FolderBarCore's default isolation (keep it nonisolated unless we have a strong reason).
- Do not do unrelated refactors; keep this focused on isolation + correctness/perf implications.

Why this matters
- The app mixes SwiftUI/AppKit UI (must be main-thread) with background work (folder scanning, thumbnails, directory watching, Sparkle). Default MainActor isolation can reduce accidental off-main UI access, but can also accidentally run too much work on the main actor if we're not explicit.

Proposed approach
1) Prototype behind Debug first
- Add SwiftPM swiftSettings for FolderBarApp + FolderBar (and possibly test targets) to pass:
  -default-isolation MainActor
- Prefer enabling this in Debug first (so we can validate behavior/perf), then decide whether to keep it for Release.

2) Audit "background" work boundaries
- Confirm heavy/IO work is explicitly off-main:
  - Folder scanning: should use Task.detached (already modernized).
  - Thumbnail generation: ensure QLThumbnailing + image decode/cache work doesn’t become main-actor by default.
  - Directory watching: ensure event handling stays responsive and doesn’t schedule heavy refresh loops on main.
  - Sparkle: should remain @MainActor for API calls, but avoid long work on main.

3) Fix compile-time fallout in the smallest way
- Expect new requirements like:
  - Adding/adjusting @MainActor annotations on UI-facing types.
  - Making helpers explicitly nonisolated or detached when appropriate.
  - Adding await hops when calling MainActor-isolated APIs from nonisolated contexts.

4) Decide + document
- If it improves safety with manageable complexity, keep it (and move from Debug-only to all configs).
- If it adds confusing churn or harms responsiveness, revert and document why (and what we’d need to adopt it later).
design:
Implementation notes
- Swift flag exists as: -default-isolation MainActor|nonisolated.
- Prefer scoping this to UI/executable targets only.
- Start Debug-only via SwiftSetting conditions (if supported) to reduce risk; then widen if successful.
- Watch for accidental main-actor inheritance in Task { } closures; use Task.detached for work that must not inherit MainActor.
acceptance_criteria:
- We can enable -default-isolation MainActor for FolderBarApp + FolderBar (at least in Debug) without breaking the build.
- swift test passes.
- ./Scripts/compile_and_run.sh works and the app remains responsive (manual smoke check: open panel, refresh list, scroll, thumbnails load, open folder picker).
- Decision recorded in the issue notes (adopted vs reverted) with rationale and any follow-ups.
close_reason: Enabled Swift -default-isolation MainActor for FolderBarApp + FolderBar to make UI/main-thread correctness the default. Marked background-facing helpers nonisolated (ThumbnailGenerating, SymbolCatalogLoading, Sleeper, SFSymbolCatalog). swift test + release build pass; compile_and_run works.

title: Enable actor data race checks (debug-only)
description:
Context
- Strict concurrency checking is enabled at compile time.
- Swift also supports runtime actor data race checks which can catch incorrect cross-actor access during development.

Goal
- Enable actor data race checks for Debug builds (and tests), while keeping Release builds unaffected.

Why this matters
- Compile-time rules catch a lot, but not everything (especially when interacting with ObjC/AppKit frameworks or complex async flows).
- Runtime checks can surface real violations early, before they become flaky UI bugs.

Proposed approach
- Add SwiftPM swiftSettings (Debug-only) to pass:
  -enable-actor-data-race-checks
- Apply to FolderBarApp + FolderBar, and test targets.
- Ensure Release builds do not include this flag.
- Add a short note to AGENTS/README on how to verify the flag is active (e.g. swift build -v and search for it) and how to disable if it’s too noisy for a particular investigation.

Risks / caveats
- These checks can add runtime overhead; keep them Debug-only.
- If it surfaces real violations, we should fix them (or file follow-up beads if they’re non-trivial).
design:
Implementation notes
- swiftc supports both -enable-actor-data-race-checks and -disable-actor-data-race-checks.
- Prefer SwiftSetting conditions to scope this to Debug (and optionally tests).
- Verification suggestion:
  - swift build -c debug -v | rg -- "enable-actor-data-race-checks"
  - swift build -c release -v | rg -- "enable-actor-data-race-checks" (should be empty)
acceptance_criteria:
- Debug build commands include -enable-actor-data-race-checks (verified via swift build -v).
- Release build does NOT include the flag.
- swift test passes.
- ./Scripts/compile_and_run.sh still launches the app.
notes: Enabled runtime actor data race checks for Debug-only builds via SwiftPM swiftSettings (-enable-actor-data-race-checks). Verified debug builds include the flag and release builds do not. Added AGENTS.md concurrency diagnostics note; swift test + ./Scripts/compile_and_run.sh pass.

Also remove the AGENTS.md note about verifying/disabling; keep config implicit/default-on.

Notes:
- Should still be possible to override temporarily via CLI flags (e.g. -Xswiftc -disable-actor-data-race-checks) without documenting it.
acceptance_criteria:

notes: Changed -enable-actor-data-race-checks from Debug-only to always-on (all configurations) via SwiftPM swiftSettings, and removed the AGENTS.md concurrency diagnostics note. Verified swift test + ./Scripts/compile_and_run.sh.

title: Disable actor data race checks for Release builds

acceptance_criteria:

title: Effort 2: Enable strict concurrency checking

Goal:
- Avoid late events after folder changes; simplify lifecycle management; align with strict concurrency.

title: Effort 7: Cooperative activation cleanup (remove ignoringOtherApps hacks)
description:

Scope:

title: Folder picker should foreground when opened
description:
Repro:
1) Click Choose Folder to open NSOpenPanel
2) Activate another app/window so the picker goes behind
3) Click Choose Folder again (from panel or Settings)

Expected: existing picker comes to front
Actual: action no-ops due to single-dialog guard; Settings Change button disabled makes it hard to find

Fix:
- Track active NSOpenPanel instance
- On repeat invocation, activate app + order the existing panel front
- Keep Settings button enabled (label becomes Show…)

Acceptance:
- Repeat clicks bring the open panel to the front
- Settings remains usable to surface the picker
close_reason: Keep Settings button copy as Change… while still focusing existing picker

title: Core models + FolderScanner (creation-date sort)
description:
Implement core models and folder scanning in FolderBarCore.

Scope:
- Add FolderConfig, FolderChildItem, and FolderSnapshot models.
- Implement FolderScanner.scan(folderURL:) to read immediate children only (no recursion).
- Use resource keys: name, isDirectory, creationDate, contentModificationDate.
- Sort by creationDate desc, falling back to contentModificationDate, then distantPast.
- No ignore rules or hidden-file filtering; include everything in the immediate directory.
acceptance_criteria:
- FolderScanner returns immediate children sorted by newest first using creationDate fallback.
- FolderChildItem includes url, name, isDirectory, creationDate.
- No recursion or filtering beyond immediate children.
